docs.lead_paragraph: Just 5 percent to 17 percent of adults suffering sore throats have bacterial infections that require antibiotics. But when sufferers see their primary care doctors, a new study reports, almost three-quarters of them will be given drugs anyway. The report suggests that many doctors are still not getting the message that excessive use of antibiotics is believed to be contributing to the growing number of drug-resistant bacteria.

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors like to speak about the medical advances that allow them to save many patients in the first hour after a heart attack. But as powerful as clot-busting drugs and other treatments are, they are of no use if heart attack patients or their families fail to seek immediate medical assistance -- a mistake that happens most of the time, studies show.
docs.abstract: American Heart Assn and federal health officials begin campaign to urge doctors to teach their patients about signs of heart attack; study finds that nearly half million Americans who die of heart attacks each year fail to seek help quickly enough (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: On the wall of her office at Mount Sinai School of Medicine in New York, Prof. Christine Cassel, 55, has hung an impressionistic still life that a friend painted shortly before dying. ''I keep it there,'' Dr. Cassel said recently, ''to remind myself of all the valiant attempts people make to find meaning at the end of their lives.'' As the head of Mount Sinai's department of geriatrics and adult development, Dr. Cassel spends much of her day seeking new ways for her patients to find meaning and comfort in their final years.

headline.main: Pushing Quality of Life Until the End

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Christine Cassel, geriatrician at Mount Sinai School of Medicine; she spends much of her day seeking new ways for her patients to find meaning and comfort in their final years; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Contests that offer smokers the chance to win money if they can prove they have quit appear effective at helping them break their addiction. Writing in the current issue of Preventive Medicine, researchers from the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., say the contests, already in use in 52 countries, offer a valuable tool for reducing smoking.
docs.abstract: Contests that offer smokers chance to win money if they can prove they have quit appear effective at helping them break their addiction (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Many doctors have learned the hard way that just giving prescriptions to patients is no guarantee that the drugs will actually be taken as directed. Now it appears that even reminding the patients makes little difference. Researchers from Ohio State University say they have found that patients who received reminders encouraging them to take their prescriptions did so at about the same rate as others who were not reminded. In both cases, one in five reported not following the doctor's instructions.
docs.abstract: Study finds that patients who receive reminders from their doctor encouraging them to take their prescription drugs do so at about same rate as those who were not reminded; in both cases, one in five report not following doctor's instructions (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Healthy people over 60 on a course to develop memory problems show distinctive changes in their brains that can be seen with PET scans, even if the people experience no symptoms, a new study reports. After tracking subjects for three years, researchers from the New York University medical school concluded that the scans could be used to predict who would develop mild cognitive impairment, a precursor of Alzheimer's disease. The study, led by Dr. Mony J. de Leon, is reported in the current issue of The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.
docs.abstract: Study shows that healthy people over 60 on course to develop memory problems show distinctive changes in their brains that can be seen with PET scans, even if people experience no symptoms (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Loss of Self: A Family Resource for the Care of Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders,'' by Dr. Donna Cohen and Dr. Carl Eisdorfer, W. W. Norton & Company, $27.95. Alzheimer's disease, the insidious stealer of the mind, has become a household word, in part because of the growing number of people afflicted -- some four million Americans of middle age and older. By 2025, an estimated 34 million worldwide will be stricken.

headline.main: Hope Is Found in the Cloud of Alzheimer's
